scientificExplanation: Research from Stanford's Sleep Lab shows sleep quality depends on **circadian rhythm alignment** and **sleep pressure accumulation**. Your circadian rhythm is controlled by light exposure: blue light from screens signals "daytime" to your brain, suppressing melatonin production for 1-3 hours. Additionally, **sleep pressure** builds through adenosine accumulation during wakefulness—but sedentary lifestyles don't build enough pressure, causing shallow sleep. Inconsistent bedtimes create **social jet lag**: your body never fully adapts to a schedule. The solution is **systematic sleep hygiene**: consistent sleep/wake times, no screens 60+ mins before bed, caffeine cutoff at 2pm, physical activity during day, and wind-down ritual.

faqs.question: Why do I sleep 8 hours but still feel exhausted?
faqs.answer: **Duration doesn't equal quality**. You might be getting 8 hours but spending too much time in light sleep and not enough in deep/REM sleep. Common causes: (1) **Inconsistent schedule**—your circadian rhythm never stabilizes, fragmenting sleep architecture. (2) **Blue light exposure**—screens before bed suppress melatonin and delay REM onset. (3) **Caffeine too late**—6-8 hour half-life means afternoon coffee disrupts deep sleep even if you fall asleep. (4) **Stress/cortisol**—elevated cortisol prevents deep sleep cycles. (5) **No sleep pressure**—sedentary days don't build adenosine, causing shallow sleep. NooLife fixes this systematically: consistent schedule locks rhythm, screen curfew optimizes melatonin, workouts build pressure, meditation reduces cortisol. By Week 4-6, same 8 hours yields 2x better quality.

faqs.question: Is it okay to have different sleep schedules on weekdays vs weekends?
faqs.answer: **No—this creates social jet lag** and is one of the worst things for sleep quality. When you sleep 11pm-6am weekdays then 1am-9am weekends, you're essentially flying to a different time zone every Friday and back every Monday. Your circadian rhythm never stabilizes. Research shows this: (1) Fragments sleep architecture (less deep/REM sleep). (2) Causes Monday grogginess (circadian misalignment). (3) Increases cortisol and reduces insulin sensitivity. The fix: **same sleep/wake time daily for 21+ days** to lock your rhythm. Yes, even weekends. After Week 6-8 when rhythm is solid, you can add 30-60 min flexibility on weekends, but during adaptation, consistency is non-negotiable. NooLife tracks this: weekend inconsistency drops your Discipline rating.

faqs.question: How late can I have caffeine without affecting sleep?
faqs.answer: **Caffeine has a 6-hour half-life**, meaning if you drink coffee at 4pm, 50% is still in your system at 10pm. Even if you fall asleep, caffeine blocks adenosine receptors, reducing deep sleep quality. Research-backed cutoff: **last caffeine by 2pm** for 10pm-11pm bedtime. If you sleep later (midnight), you can extend to 3pm, but not later. Additionally, **total daily caffeine matters**: 400mg+ daily (4 cups) can disrupt sleep even with early cutoff. NooLife tracks this through your daily habits. If your sleep quality is poor and you're drinking afternoon coffee, the app flags it. By Week 3-4 of 2pm cutoff, you'll notice: faster sleep onset, deeper sleep, better morning energy. Caffeine works better when your sleep is optimized—you need less of it.

faqs.question: What's the best wind-down routine before bed?
faqs.answer: The ideal wind-down ritual signals to your body that sleep is approaching. Research-backed components: (1) **Screen curfew (60-90 mins before bed)**: Blue light suppresses melatonin for 1-3 hours—this is non-negotiable. (2) **Dim lighting**: Bright lights delay melatonin. Use lamps, not overhead lights, after 9pm. (3) **Low-stimulation activities**: Reading (physical books), stretching, journaling, meditation. Avoid work, intense conversations, or news (cortisol spikes). (4) **Consistent timing**: Same routine, same time nightly (e.g., 10pm-11pm every night). (5) **Temperature drop**: Hot shower 90 mins before bed causes core temp drop afterward, signaling sleep. NooLife prescribes this: reading (screen-free), meditation (stress reduction), consistent sleep time (rhythm lock). By Week 3-4, the ritual becomes automatic—your body starts producing melatonin when you begin the routine.

faqs.question: Should I use sleep trackers or apps?
faqs.answer: **Sleep trackers are useful for data, not solutions**. They can show you: sleep duration, restlessness, potential sleep debt. But they can't fix your circadian rhythm or sleep hygiene—behavioral change does that. Additionally, some people develop **orthosomnia** (obsession with perfect sleep data) causing sleep anxiety. Use trackers to: (1) Establish baseline (how much deep/REM you're getting). (2) Measure improvement after behavior changes. (3) Identify patterns (caffeine days = worse sleep). But don't rely on them for solutions. NooLife is different: it **prescribes the behaviors** that improve sleep (consistent schedule, workouts, meditation, screen curfew) and tracks your compliance. You're changing the inputs (behaviors), which changes the output (sleep quality). By Week 6, you'll feel the difference without needing a tracker.
